content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A projectile launcher, shown in Figure 1, can launch small blocks that have a certain size and shape. The launcher uses an internal spring, which cannot be removed and is not accessible, that is always compressed by the same distance prior to launching a block. A group of students wish to experimentally determine the amount of energy <math alttext="E sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math> that is stored in the spring prior to a launch. The students have a collection of blocks of different mass that are all of the right size and shape to be used in the launcher. (a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine <math alttext="E sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math> by making a linear graph. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A projectile launcher, shown in Figure 1, can launch small blocks that have a certain size and shape. The launcher uses an internal spring, which cannot be removed and is not accessible, that is always compressed by the same distance prior to launching a block. A group of students wish to experimentally determine the amount of energy <math alttext="E sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math> that is stored in the spring prior to a launch. The students have a collection of blocks of different mass that are all of the right size and shape to be used in the launcher. (a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine <math alttext="E sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math> by making a linear graph. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph could be used to determine the value of <math alttext="E sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math>.

The students determine that the launcher spring stores <math alttext="0.452 joule" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.452</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext></math> of energy. In their next experiment, they wish to experimentally determine the coefficient of kinetic friction <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math> between the blocks and the floor in their classroom. Although the blocks have different masses, the outer surfaces of the blocks are all made of the same material and therefore have the same coefficient of kinetic friction with the floor.The students lay the launcher on the floor, as shown in Figure 2, and launch a number of the blocks horizontally along the floor. They measure each block’s final position <math alttext="x sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> on a line along the blocks’ launch path. The table shows the results of the experiment.Block Mass <math alttext="mass, in kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>Final Position <math alttext="x sub f, in meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="0.050" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.050</mn></math><math alttext="4.110" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.110</mn></math><math alttext="0.080" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.080</mn></math><math alttext="2.357" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.357</mn></math><math alttext="0.100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.100</mn></math><math alttext="1.840" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.840</mn></math><math alttext="0.200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.200</mn></math><math alttext="1.325" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.325</mn></math><math alttext="0.350" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.350</mn></math><math alttext="0.776" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.776</mn></math>

(c)i. Indicate what quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>.Horizontal axis:__________ Vertical axis:__________Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units.

ii. On the following grid, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.

(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii) and the energy value of <math alttext="0.452 joule" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.452</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext></math>, calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
